text: I just coming off house the devil I
didn't want to make anything necessarily
like that but at a similar budget range
you can only do so much different and I
you know I wanted to make something that
had a lot of humor in it and that segue
into a very traditional old-fashioned
ghost story in a very old-fashioned
hotel but i liked the modern aspect of
it being like these nerds in a building
that's from the 1800's been bad 70s
renovation and these kind of like
modern-day nerds with part-time jobs
that they don't really totally care
about and I like those people being in a
very traditional like old-fashioned
ghost story because it doesn't make
sense and seeing how that would play out
and I thought that that would create a
really good dynamic and make the
contrast between the horror and this
sort of like hanging out as broad as
possible to when the horror came in it
was really unsettling because I really
wanted to charm I want to make a
charming movie and I wanted to charm
everyone into this movie so that way
when it starts getting scary you're
actually really uncomfortable by it
because these characters don't belong in
this movie and so when it starts to turn
the har movie the both the audience and
the characters are in over their head
and that's what I was really trying to
accomplish well I think especially
horror audiences and become so hip and
postmodern to like techniques of
filmmaking and specifically genre movies
that they're generally they almost want
to be a step ahead of the filmmaker
which I don't understand because it kind
of makes the movie less interesting but
that's for some reason the audience's
they're just really attuned to like all
the tricks of you know opening the
mirror close the mirror and it's behind
you or all the gangs so what I tried to
do is set up a lot of familiar you know
harder tropes but but do something
different with them to where the people
oh I know it's going to happen he's
going to do this into this and then that
doesn't happen and then you get to
another situation oh you know it's going
to happen he's going to go in there it's
going to pop out but I do something a
little bit different to the point where
enough of times that happens it was the
same thing with houses a devil like you
mess with people's some of their
expectations it's like their assumptions
you mess with those as much as you can
to the point where they now go I don't
know what's going to happen anymore and
then you go back to actually being tense
and being like it was before you were
hip and postmodern and that's what I try
to accomplish with like
you know some of the denied and jump
scares they're like jump jokes you know
which is like it's not really a elbow
when the ribs are a wink at the audience
but it's a little bit of a like I'm
ahead of you on this one you know so
just stop trying to think you know
what's going on and just watch the movie
that's generally my approach to it's the
same with houses devil was like when
she's walking around the house and
everyone's like oh it's going to be as
it's like I'm ahead of you I know
there's only one step but I'm just
enough that you know you need to just
watch the movie and stop trying to
figure out what's gonna happen cuz you
know and I do the same thing you know
it's like as a filmmaker especially you
just you you and plus movies have become
such lowest common denominator that
they're all the same so you know like
how she opens thinking the ironing board
falls out you know it's like all those
gags and they keep using them in movies
so I was adamant about using variations
of those but skewing them a little bit
